The Gulf of Finland, part of the Baltic Sea, has lower salinity and colder temperatures than the North Atlantic, which could potentially slow corrosion. However, its shallower depths and possibly higher oxygen levels might accelerate decay compared to the deeper, darker waters of the North Atlantic. While the lower salinity in the Baltic Sea might offer some preservation benefits, the Titanic's current location in the North Atlantic is generally more conducive to its preservation due to colder temperatures and lower oxygen levels. Therefore, the Titanic would not be as well preserved in the Gulf of Finland as it is in its current resting place.

The Titanic, if hypothetically placed at the bottom of the Gulf of Finland, would likely be better preserved due to the colder, less saline environment of the Baltic Sea, which slows corrosion and biological activity. This contrasts with the North Atlantic's warmer currents and more active marine life, which contribute to the Titanic's ongoing decomposition. Therefore, the Gulf of Finland's conditions would indeed support better preservation of the Titanic.
